documents.title: that 's it ! thank you for all your questions
text: guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:13pm thanks for your funny interesting questions everyone .
steven bremner asks : do you regret dragging that giant trophy onto the stage at the edinburgh festival a few years ago ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:12pm hello steven .
this is my favourite question .
all the nominees for the fosters award have to perform for a fosters night at the end of the festival , which i won that year .
all the male losers backstage ( who did n't win ) encouraged me to drag this huge prop of a gold award statue on stage , as if it was very heavy and made of gold .
i said it would confuse the audience and not get a laugh , but that i would do it anyway .
i took ages dragging it across the huge stage to complete silence , but had to commit to it in the hope that it would be a slow burner , and people would eventually start laughing , but no-one did .
and then my set went really badly .
i expect all the male losers backstage were wondering how the hell i managed to beat them .
i often wonder myself .
and no , i do n't regret doing it .
returnmyjedi asks : the bends , or ok computer ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:04pm both .
thanks .
markell1991 asks : depends what you mean does n't it ?
you can just say wine or cheese .
you have to put it into some kind of context .
it 's obviously a trick .
okay .
you 're at a supermarket .

there 's a rather lovely cheese display ( featuring an appearance from some very interesting chili brie ) on one of the aisles , however on another there is a display of the latest vineal offerings from multiple countries .
what do you go for ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:04pm the latest vineal offerings from multiple countries .
thanks for the clarification .
hoffman wannabe asks : what 's the best falafel you have ever had ?
the stall at berwick street market is my personal favourite .
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:02pm i 'm really glad you like the stall at berwick street , make sure you let them know how much you like their falafels .
the best falafel i had was in a wimpy on august 4th , 1983 , at 1.20pm , in kings square in gloucester .
i was wearing trousers from c & a .
hoffman wannabe asks : when is the last time you went to a wimpy ?
if neither when is the last time you saw a wimpy ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 2:01pm the last time i went to a wimpy was august 4th , 1983 , in king 's square in gloucester .
it was 1.20pm .
i was wearing trousers from c & a .

documents.title: `` a breakthrough i had was the realisation that being silly about something does not demean it . ''
text: id384208 asks : now that your shows are a well deserved success , are you tempted to go back to your older style and add more clowning alongside the bigger issues ?
also , how would you describe your stand-up writing process ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:59pm hello .
yes , i will definitely be doing more clowning , in fact i have n't really worked out how best to deliver the bigger issues yet .
in my head it 's somewhere between the stuff i used to do and what i 'm doing now .
there 's not enough variation in my delivery yet , but that will come with time i expect , if i keep going .
a breakthrough i had was the realisation that being silly about something does not demean it .
it 's about tone and context .

documents.title: `` sleaford mods are my favourite live band ''
text: spaknapak asks : do you like the sleaford mods ?
does their general anger with the world in 2015 chime with your views ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:50pm yes i love them - i think they 're absolutely brilliant .
they 're my favourite live band .
i have seen them three times .
their on-stage personas are hypnotic .
i have n't seen anything like them before .
we the audience seem completely irrelevant to them it 's almost as if we 're an inconvenience and they do n't care if we 're there or not .
and that 's very powerful .
it 's what i 'm aiming for .
of course i have to be absolutely brilliant before i can be so arrogant on stage , and that 's a while off yet .
joe bradbury asks : hi bridget , morrissey has filed a sexual assault complaint against an airport security officer who allegedly groped his penis and testicles .
the case has been dismissed as yet another archetypal morrissey faux pas , despite obvious distress from the ex-smith .
do you think this assumption would be different if morrissey was a woman ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:44pm yes , it would be different if morrissey was a woman .
the woman would n't have filed a sexual assault complaint in the first place , because she 'd know she would n't taken seriously anyway .
supermanhatescomics asks : what you you rather have , a fist that can go back in time and punch someone or the ability to control specifically white rabbits ?
serious answers only please .
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:41pm i 'd rather have the ability to go back in time and punch white rabbits .
no , i would n't , i really like white rabbits , and all the other different coloured rabbits you can get .

documents.title: `` my other favourite christie ? agatha . ''
text: id5279263 asks : john , agatha , julie , linford , who 's your favourite other christie ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:38pm agatha .

documents.title: `` i hate grooming . it 's embarrassing . ''
text: herrdobler asks : hilary clinton has been bemoaning the amount of time she has to spend on her grooming regime and spends $ 600 on a haircut ( twice that with colour apparently ) .
as a feminist , she presumably considers this upkeep a price worth paying for the greater good of getting her political voice heard .
do you relate to hilary 's image quandary ?
would you recommend she dresses as charles ii at rallies to bypass the problem ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:37pm excuse me , herrdobler , i 'll have you know that that charles ii grooming regime took all day .
i 'm deeply wounded that you would think that i would just quickly draw a moustache on my upper lip with a pencil and put some buckled shoes on , and would be able to get the result that i did .
even the daily mail thought i was the actual charles ii ( have you read my book ?
you will like this bit ) .
i 'd be interested to know how long it takes you to look like charles ii .
i hate grooming .
it 's embarrassing .
i like grooming my cat though , to look like charles ii .
luckily i 'm a comedian so it really does n't matter what i look like at all - not to me , anyway .
in fact , the worse i look , the better it is for my comedy .
john stringer asks : i saw one of your edinburgh previews last year ; i wish i lived in the uk so i could see you again !
when you suddenly changed gears from hilarity to fgm , i felt that i cried out with shock and surprise .
is that a common reaction ?
do you expect it ?
or should i have been embarrassed ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:26pm hello john .
where do you live ?
anyway , thanks for coming .
the gear changes are deliberate .

i try not to have big boring serious setups for the more difficult subjects , and just drop them in unexpectedly so that by the time you 've thought about how horrible the thing i 've just mentioned is , i 'm already onto a silly bit .
lostlegend asks : is the edinburgh fringe a have to do or a want to do ?
if you could avoid doing 20 odd nights in the same city as thousands of other shows would you or do you genuinely look forward to the monk and enjoy the festival whilst here ?
your show is sold out so i guess you can be more honest than most on this ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:21pm i do n't feel like i have to do a new show in edinburgh every year , but i want to .
if i did n't , i would feel a year behind developmentally in terms of my writing , and performing , and working out how to be a better standup .
it 's become very expensive , due to rents and venue hire costs for acts , so many of them feel like they ca n't justify the debt .
especially if their show does n't generate any other work .
some comics see it as an opportunity to boost their profiles or to be spotted .
i do n't see much comedy while i 'm up there , and try to see shows from other countries that i would n't otherwise get a chance to see .
i would probably go even if i was n't performing myself .
doing 20 nights in edinburgh while the festival is on , is a huge privilege so i really look forward to going every year .

documents.title: `` i do n't mind being called a feminist comedian because i 'm a feminist and a comedian ''
text: highwaytoshel asks : do you feel that feminist comedy ' and feminist comedians ' need that label ?
why is it there ?
i 'm a feminist but i do n't wear feminist approved shoes or drink feminist approved lager !
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:11pm hello , highwaytoshel .
i did n't give myself that label , the media did .
i do n't mind being called a feminist comedian because i 'm a feminist and a comedian , but it 's not necessary or how i define my comedy personally .
if i start talking about paper or something , i expect they 'll call me the 'paper comedian ' .
id0377017 asks : will it be hard to write a show that is n't feminist comedy after the recent success of your shows , radio and now book ?

while it 's unlikely that the need for raising gender imbalances will go away anytime soon i would imagine as a performer that there are plenty of other things ( or historical characters ) that you would like to tackle .
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:08pm no , it wo n't be hard .
i never plan anything , i just write about what i 'm into at any given time .

hufenfa asks : whether it 's the bizarre procedures women do to chase youth ( labial surgery is like pollarding a tree ) is it ok to criticise women for anything they do , and if not should n't you rewrite your webchat intro ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:07pm yes of course it 's ok to criticise women .
and you , you idiot .
markell1991 asks : wine or cheese ?
guardian contributor bridgetchristie 03 august 2015 1:06pm depends what you mean does n't it ?
you can just say `` wine or cheese '' .
you have to put it into some kind of context .
it 's obviously a trick .

documents.title: bridget christie is in the building !
text: bridget is in the guardian offices ready to answer your questions

documents.title: post your questions for bridget christie
text: in a world where women in comedy are still often treated as a subgenre , bridget christie is invaluable .

her standup sets and her writing in this year 's a book for her are angry to the point of amused bewilderment , railing against the inequalities women still have to face even after decades of feminism .

whether it 's the bizarre procedures women do to chase youth ( labial surgery is like pollarding a tree ) or the constant diminishing of women in advertising , christie blends rabble-rousing campaigns with laughs , as she points out the absurdities of modern female life .
she 's taking her new show , also called a book for her , to the edinburgh festival this summer , and ahead of her run she 's joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat .
it runs from 1pm bst onwards on monday 3 august post your questions for bridget in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
